Example

Suppose that we have a triangle \(ABC\) where \(AB = 5\)cm, \(BC=3cm\) and angle \(B = 50^\circ\). Find the length of the remaining side of the triangle.

Solution

Note that the remaining side of the triangle is the side \(AC\) which corresponds to the symbol \(b\) in the cosine rule. Thus from the cosine rule we have \[ b^2 = a^2 + c^2 - 2ac\cos B. \] In this case we have \(a = 3, c = 5\) and \(B = 50^\circ\), so substituting these into the above equation we obtain \[ AC^2 = b^2 = 3^2 + 5^2 - (2 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot \cos 50^\circ) = 34 - 30 \cdot 50^\circ \approx 14.7 \: \mbox{cm}. \]
